title: 02_duality
text:
Optimization Theory and Practice


Duality and Complementarity




Instructor: Aykut Satici, Ph.D.Â   Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering  Electrical and Computer Engineering  Boise State University, Boise, ID, USA


Topics:  Dual Linear Programs  The Duality Theorem  Interpretations  Sensitivity and CS

title: 02_duality
02_duality
02_duality
text:
General Procedure for Conversion



The dual of the dual is the primal!




The objective coefficient vector of the primal becomes the right-hand-side vector of the dual constraints,
The right-hand-side vector of the primal constraints becomes the objective coefficient vector of the dual,
The transpose of the constraint matrix of the primal becomes the constraint matrix of the dual,
Every primal variable corresponds o a constraint in the dual, and its sign decides the sense of the dual constraint,
Every primal constraint corresponds to a variable in the dual, and its sense decides the sign of the dual variable.

title: 02_duality
text:
Example 1


max2x1+x2(dual var.)s.t.x1+83x2â‰¤4,(y1)x1+x2â‰¤2(y2)2x1â‰¤3(y3)x1,x2â‰¥0.\begin{align}
\operatorname{max} & 2x_1 + x_2 & (\text{dual var.}) \\
\text{s.t.} & x_1 + \frac{8}{3}x_2 \leq 4, & (y_1) \\
& x_1 + x_2 \leq 2 & (y_2) \\
& 2x_1 \leq 3 & (y_3) \\
& x_1, x_2 \geq 0.
\end{align}

min4y1+2y2+3y3(primal var.)s.t.y1+y2+2y3â‰¥2,(x1)83y1+y2â‰¥1,(x2)y1,y2,y3â‰¥0.\begin{align}
\operatorname{min} & 4y_1 + 2y_2 + 3y_3 & (\text{primal var.}) \\
\text{s.t.} & y_1 + y_2 + 2y_3 \geq 2, & (x_1) \\
& \frac{8}{3}y_1 + y_2 \geq 1, & (x_2) \\
& y_1, y_2, y_3 \geq 0.
\end{align}







Dual can be viewed as the acquisition pricing problem: a buyer sets the prices for the three resources of the producer:

each of the constraints indicates that the prices are competitive or even better than producing each product by the producer itself,
the objective is to minimize the total acuisition cost.

title: 02_duality
section: Example 2 â€“ Dual of the Diet Problem
text:
Example 2 â€“ Dual of the Diet Problem


This problem has the form on the right and hence can be regarded as the primal problem of the symmetric pair.

minimizeğœâŠ¤ğ±subject toğ€ğ±â‰¥ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} \geq \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}
\end{align}








Dual Interpretation


Imagine a pharmaceutical company that prodcues in pill form each of the nutrients considered important by the dietitian. The company tries to convince the dietitian to buy pills, and thereby supply the nutrients directly rather than through purchase of various foods.

The company must decide the positive unit prices: y1,y2,â€¦,ymy_1, y_2, \ldots, y_m for the nutrients so as to maximize revenue while at the same time being competitive with real food.
The cost of a unit food ii made synthetically from pure nutrients bought from the druggist must be no greater than cic_i, the market price of the food.
Thus, denoting by ğši\bm{a}_i the ithi^{\text{th}} food, the company must satisfy ğ²âŠ¤ğšiâ‰¤ğœi\bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_i \leq \bm{c}_i for each ii.
Since bjb_j units of the jthj^{\text{th}} nutrient will be purchased, the problem of the druggist is on the right.





Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
maximizeğ²âŠ¤ğ›subject toğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤,ğ²â‰¥ğŸ
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top\bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top, \quad \bm{y} \geq \bm{0}
\end{align}

title: 02_duality
section: Example 3 â€“ Dual of the Transportation Problem
text:
Example 3 â€“ Dual of the Transportation Problem



Recall that this is the problem, faced by the manufacturer, of selecting the pattern of product shipments between several fixed origins and desginations so as to minimize transportation cost while satisfying demand.






The primal is in standard form

minimizeâˆ‘i,jcijxijsubject toâˆ‘j=1nxij=ai,i=1,2,â€¦,m,âˆ‘i=1mxij=bj,j=1,2,â€¦,n,xijâ‰¥0,i=1,2,â€¦,m;j=1,2,â€¦,n.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \sum_{i,j} c_{ij}x_{ij} \\
\text{subject to} & \sum_{j=1}^n x_{ij} = a_i, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, m, \\
& \sum_{i=1}^m x_{ij} = b_j, \quad j = 1, 2, \ldots, n, \\
& x_{ij} \geq 0, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, m; \, j = 1, 2, \ldots, n.
\end{align}



The asymmetric version of the duality relation applies.

maximizeâˆ‘i=1maiui+âˆ‘j=1nbjvjsubject toui+vjâ‰¤cij,i=1,2,â€¦,m;j=1,2,â€¦,n.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \sum_{i=1}^m a_iu_i + \sum_{j=1}^n b_jv_j \\
\text{subject to} & u_i + v_j \leq c_{ij}, \quad i = 1, 2, \ldots, m; \; j = 1,
2, \ldots, n.
\end{align}






Interpretation


Imagine that the company, responsible for shipping the product quantities from the origins to the destinations, plans to launch a new and simplified â€œpricingâ€ scheme to the manufacturer:

charge $ui{\$}u_i for every unit shipped out from origin site ii; and $vj\$v_j for every unit shipped to the destination site jj.
The shipping company would select unit prices/costs u1,u2,â€¦,umu_1, u_2, \ldots, u_m for the mm origins and v1,v2,â€¦,vnv_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n for the nn destinations such that ui+vjâ‰¤ciju_i + v_j \leq c_{ij} for all i,ji, j.

This is to convince the manufacturer customer to accept the new scheme since ui+vju_i+ v_j represents the net amount the manufacturer must pay to ship a unit of product from origin ii to destination jj.

title: 02_duality
section: Example 4 â€“ Dual of the MDP Problem
text:
Example 4 â€“ Dual of the MDP Problem



Recall that the MDP problem is to find to find the optimal cost-to-go value yiy_i for state i=1,2,â€¦,mi = 1, 2, \ldots, m such that





maximizeâˆ‘i=1myisubject toyiâˆ’Î³ğ©jâŠ¤ğ²â‰¤cj,âˆ€jâˆˆğ’œi,âˆ€i=1,â€¦,m.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \sum_{i=1}^m y_i & \\
\text{subject to} & y_i - \gamma \bm{p}_j^\top \bm{y} \leq c_j, & \forall j
\in \mathcal{A}_i, \\
& & \forall i = 1, \ldots, m.
\end{align}


The dual problem would be
minimizeâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘jâˆˆğ’œjcjxjsubject toâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘jâˆˆğ’œi(ğiâˆ’Î³ğ©j)xj=ğŸ,xjâ‰¥0,âˆ€jâˆˆğ’œi,âˆ€i=1,â€¦,m,
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j \in \mathcal{A}_j} c_j x_j \\
\text{subject to} & \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j \in \mathcal{A}_i} (\bm{e}_i - \gamma
\bm{p}_j)x_j = \bm{1}, \\
& x_j \geq 0, \;\; \forall j \in \mathcal{A}_i, \;\; \forall i = 1, \ldots, m,
\end{align}

where ği\bm{e}_i is the unit vector with 11 for the ithi^{\text{th}} entry and 00 everywhere else.







Variable xjx_j, jâˆˆğ’œij \in \mathcal{A}_i represents the expected total discounted present frequency, or the total expected present number of times taking action jj in a state ii, during the process.







Since cjc_j is the immediate cost of taking action jj once, cjxjc_jx_j represents the total expected present cost of taking action jj during the process so that the objective of the dual represents the overall expected present cost of the entire process.






When the objective of the dual is minimized, only one flux/frequency in each state would be positive, which establishes an optimal policy.

title: 02_duality
text:
Weak Duality
Throughout this section, we consider the primal-dual pair


minimizeğœâŠ¤ğ±subject toğ€ğ±=ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align}


maximizeğ²âŠ¤ğ›subject toğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.
\end{align}






Weak Duality Lemma


If ğ±\bm{x} and ğ²\bm{y} are feasible for the primal-dual pair, then ğœâŠ¤ğ±â‰¥ğ²âŠ¤ğ›\bm{c}^\top\bm{x} \geq \bm{y}^\top\bm{b}.






Proof


We have ğ²âŠ¤ğ›=ğ²âŠ¤ğ€ğ±â‰¤ğœâŠ¤ğ±, \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} = \bm{y}^\top \bm{Ax} \leq \bm{c}^\top \bm{x},  the last inequality being valid sincd ğ±â‰¥ğŸ\bm{x} \geq \bm{0} and ğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤\bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.








Corollary


If ğ±0\bm{x}_0 and ğ²0\bm{y}_0 are feasible for the primal-dual pair and if ğœâŠ¤ğ±0=ğ²0âŠ¤ğ›\bm{c}^\top \bm{x}_0 = \bm{y}_0^\top \bm{b}, then ğ±0\bm{x}_0 and ğ²0\bm{y}_0 are optimal for their respective problems.

title: 02_duality
text:
Strong Duality



Duality Theorem of LP


If either of the primal-dual pair problems has a finite optimal solution, so does the other, and the corresponding values of the objective functions are equal. If either problem has an unbounded objective, the other problem has no feasible solution.






Proof


Firstly, the second statement is an immediate consequence of weak duality. If the primal is unbounded and ğ²\bm{y} is feasible for the dual, we must have ğ²âŠ¤ğ›â‰¤âˆ’M\bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \leq -M for arbitrarily large MM, which is clearly impossible.
Let us assume that the primal has a finite optimal solution and show that the dual has a solution with the same value (recall primal/dual are reversible). We prove that if the primal problem is feasible and its minimal value is bounded from below, then the system
ğ€ğ±=ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ,ğ€âŠ¤ğ²â‰¤ğœ,ğœâŠ¤ğ±âˆ’ğ›âŠ¤ğ²â‰¤0(1)
\begin{align}
\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, &\quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}, \\
\bm{A}^\top \bm{y} &\leq \bm{c}, \\
\bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - &\bm{b}^\top \bm{y} \leq 0
\end{align}
 \qquad(1)
has a feasible solution pair ğ±\bm{x} and ğ²\bm{y}. The first system in EquationÂ 1 is the primal constraint system, the second is the dual constraint system, and the third is the reversed duality gap, which, together with weak duality, implies zero-duality gap ğœâŠ¤ğ±âˆ’ğ›âŠ¤ğ²=0\bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \bm{b}^\top \bm{y} = 0.

title: 02_duality
text:
Strong Duality



Proof - Continued -


We first show that the dual must be feasible, since otherwise, from Farkasâ€™s lemma the algernative system to the second system EquationÂ 1 must be feasible, that is, there is ğ±â€²â‰¥ğŸ\bm{x}^\prime \geq \bm{0} such that (ğ€ğ±â€²=ğŸ,ğœâŠ¤ğ±â€²=âˆ’1)(\bm{Ax^\prime} = \bm{0}, \; \bm{c}^\top\bm{x}^\prime = -1). Let ğ±\bm{x} be any given feasible solution for the primal, then the solution ğ±+Î±ğ±â€²\bm{x} + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime must also be feasible fro the primal for any scalar Î±>0\alpha > 0. But the primal objective value at this solution is ğœâŠ¤(x+Î±ğ±â€²)=ğœâŠ¤ğ±+Î±ğœâŠ¤ğ±â€²=ğœâŠ¤ğ±âˆ’Î±
\bm{c}^\top(x + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime) = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} + \alpha \bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^\prime = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \alpha
 which is unbounded from below as Î±â†’âˆ\alpha \rightarrow \infty leading to a contradiction.
Now, both the primal and the dual are feasible but suppose their optimal values are not equal; that is, the whole system EquationÂ 1 remains infeasible. Then its alternative system must be feasible. That is, there are (ğ²â€²,ğ±â€²,Ï„)(\bm{y}^\prime, \bm{x}^\prime, \tau) to satisfy the constraints ğ€ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ›Ï„=ğŸ,ğ€âŠ¤ğ²â€²âˆ’ğœÏ„â‰¤ğŸ,ğ›âŠ¤ğ²â€²âˆ’ğœâŠ¤ğ±â€²=1,ğ±â€²â‰¥0,Ï„â‰¥0.(2) \bm{Ax^\prime} - \bm{b}\tau = \bm{0}, \quad \bm{A}^\top \bm{y}^\prime -
\bm{c}\tau \leq \bm{0}, \quad \bm{b}^\top \bm{y}^\prime - \bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^\prime = 1, \quad \bm{x}^\prime \geq 0, \quad \tau \geq 0.  \qquad(2)
Case 1: Ï„>0\tau > 0 in EquationÂ 2, then we have 0â‰¥(âˆ’ğ²â€²)âŠ¤(ğ€ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ›Ï„)+(ğ±â€²)âŠ¤(ğ€âŠ¤ğ²â€²âˆ’ğœÏ„)=Ï„(ğ›âŠ¤ğ²â€²âˆ’ğœâŠ¤ğ±â€²)=Ï„ 0 \geq (-\bm{y}^\prime)^\top (\bm{Ax^\prime} - \bm{b}\tau) +
(\bm{x}^\prime)^\top (\bm{A}^\top \bm{y}^\prime - \bm{c}\tau) =
\tau(\bm{b}^\top\bm{y}^\prime - \bm{c}^\top \bm{x}^\prime) = \tau  which is a contradiction.
Case 2: Ï„=0\tau = 0 in EquationÂ 2, then we let ğ±\bm{x} be any feasible solution for the primal and ğ²\bm{y} be any feasible solution for the dual. Again ğ±+Î±ğ±â€²\bm{x} + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime must also be feasible for the primal and ğ²+Î±ğ²â€²\bm{y} + \alpha \bm{y}^\prime must also be feasible for the dual, and the objective gap at this pair is ğœâŠ¤(ğ±+Î±ğ±â€²)âˆ’ğ›âŠ¤(ğ²+Î±ğ²â€²)=ğœâŠ¤ğ±âˆ’ğ›âŠ¤ğ²+Î±(ğœâŠ¤ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ›âŠ¤ğ²â€²)=ğœâŠ¤ğ±âˆ’ğ›âŠ¤ğ²âˆ’Î± \bm{c}^\top(\bm{x} + \alpha \bm{x}^\prime) - \bm{b}^\top(\bm{y} + \alpha
\bm{y}^\prime) = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \bm{b}^\top \bm{y} + \alpha(\bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^\prime - \bm{b}^\top \bm{y}^\prime) = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} - \bm{b}^\top
\bm{y} - \alpha  which is not bounded below by 00 as Î±â†’âˆ\alpha \rightarrow \infty and creates a contradition to weak duality.

title: 02_duality
text:
Primal-Dual Optimal Solutions



Suppose that for the LP in the standard primal form minimizeğœâŠ¤ğ±subject toğ€ğ±=ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ,(3)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0},
\end{align}
 \qquad(3) we have the optimal basic feasible solution ğ±=(ğ±B,ğŸ)\bm{x} = (\bm{x}_B, \bm{0}) with the corresponding basis ğ\bm{B}.

Â 

Partition ğ€=[ğğƒ]\bm{A} = \begin{bmatrix} \bm{B} & \bm{D} \end{bmatrix}, where the primal basic feasible solution ğ±ğ=ğâˆ’1ğ›\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{B}^{-1}\bm{b} is optimal.



We shall determine a solution of the dual program

maximizeğ²âŠ¤ğ›subject toğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤,(4)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top\bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top,
\end{align}
 \qquad(4) in terms of ğ\bm{B}.

Define ğ²âŠ¤=ğœğâŠ¤ğâˆ’1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1}, which i s adual basic solution (The components of ğœğ\bm{c}_{\bm{B}} are those of ğœ\bm{c} assoc. w/ the columns of the submatrix ğ\bm{B} according to the same index order.).




If, in addition, ğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤\bm{y}^\top\bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top, then ğ²\bm{y} is feasible and a basic feasible solution for the dual â€” an extreme point of the dual feasible region. On the other hand

ğ²âŠ¤ğ›=ğœğâŠ¤ğâˆ’1ğ›=ğœğâŠ¤ğ±ğ,
\bm{y}^\top\bm{b} = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1}\bm{b} =
\bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top\bm{x}_{\bm{B}},

and thus the value of the dual objective function for the ğ²\bm{y} is equal to the value of the primal problem. Hence ğ²\bm{y} is optimal for the dual!

title: 02_duality
text:
Primal-Dual Optimal Solution â€“ Example



Theorem


Let the linear program EquationÂ 3 have an optimal basic feasible solution corresponding to the basis ğ\bm{B}. Then the vector ğ²\bm{y} satisfying ğ²âŠ¤=ğœğâŠ¤ğâˆ’1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1} is an optimal soluion to the dual program EquationÂ 4 if it is dual feasible. The optimal values of both problems are equal.







Primal

minimize18x1+12x2+2x3+6x4subject to3x1+x2âˆ’2x3+x4=2x1+3x2âˆ’x4=2x1,x2,x3,x4â‰¥0.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & 18x_1 + 12x_2 + 2x_3 + 6x_4 \\
\text{subject to} & 3x_1 + x_2 - 2x_3 + x_4 = 2 \\
& x_1 + 3x_2 - x_4 = 2 \\
& x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4 \geq 0.
\end{align}





Columns of ğ€\bm{A} and ğ›\bm{b} are represented in the requirement space.
A basic solution represents construction of ğ›\bm{b} with positive weights, xjx_jâ€™s, on two of the ğšj\bm{a}_jâ€™s.
Primal problem: find weights for the conic combination of ğ›\bm{b} by these columns such that the weighted sum (by cjc_jâ€™s) of the weights is minimized.













Dual

maximize2Î»1+2Î»2subject to3Î»1+Î»2â‰¤18,Î»1+3Î»2â‰¤12âˆ’2Î»1â‰¤2,Î»1âˆ’Î»2â‰¤6.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{maximize} & 2\lambda_1 + 2\lambda_2 & \\
\text{subject to} & 3\lambda_1 + \lambda_2 \leq 18, & \lambda_1 + 3\lambda_2 \leq 12 \\
& -2\lambda_1 \leq 2, & \lambda_1 - \lambda_2 \leq 6.
\end{align}





Each column ğšj\bm{a}_j of the primal defines a constraint of the dual as a half-space whose boundary is âŠ¥\perp to that column vector and is located at a point determined by cjc_j.
Dual obj. is maximized at an extreme point of the dual feasible region.

At this point exactly two dual constraints are active.
These active constraints also correspond to an optimal basis of the primal.

The vector defining the dual objective is a conic combination of the active constraint vectors: ğ›=x1ğš1+x2ğš2\bm{b} = x_1\bm{a}_1 + x_2\bm{a}_2, with xix_iâ€™s being the optimal solution of the primal!

title: 02_duality
text:
Dual Multipliers â€” Shadow Prices

ğ²âŠ¤=ğœğâŠ¤ğâˆ’1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1} is not a solution to the dual unless ğ\bm{B} is an optimal basis for the primal.

The vector ğ²\bm{y} may be used at every step to calculate the relative cost coefficients or reduced gradients (to be introduced later).
ğ²âŠ¤=ğœğâŠ¤ğâˆ’1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1} is called the vector of simplex multipliers or shadow prices.

The components of the ğšj\bm{a}_jâ€™s and ğ›\bm{b} tells us how to construct these vectors from the ği\bm{e}_iâ€™s.
Given any basis ğ\bm{B}, any other vector can be constructed (synthetically) as a linear combination of these basis vectors.

If there is a unit cost cjc_j associated with each basis vector ğšj\bm{a}_j, then the cost of a (synthetic) vector constructed from the basis can be calculated as the corresponding linear combination of the cjc_jâ€™s associated with the basis.
In particular, the cost of ği\bm{e}_i, when constructed from the basis ğ\bm{B}, is yiy_i.
Thus the yiy_iâ€™s can be interpreted as synthetic prices of the unit vectors.

title: 02_duality
text:
Dual Multipliers â€” Shadow Prices

Any vector can be expressed in terms of the basis ğ\bm{B} in two steps:

express the unit vector ği\bm{e}_i in terms of the basis,
express the desired vector as a linear combination of the ği\bm{e}_iâ€™s.

The corresponding synthetic cost of a vector constructed from the basis ğ\bm{B} can be correspondingly computed directly by:

find the synthetic price of the ğši\bm{a}_iâ€™s.
use these prices to evaluate the cost of the linear combination of ği\bm{e}_iâ€™s.

Thus, the simplex multipliers can be used to quickly evaluate the synthetic cost of any vector that is expressed in terms of the unit vectors ği\bm{e}_iâ€™s.
The difference between the true cost of this vector and the synthetic cost is the relative cost.

The process of calculating the syntheic cost of a vector w.r.t. a given basis by using the simplex multipliers is sometimes referred to as pricing out the vector.





Optimality of the primal corresponds to the situation where every vector ğš1,ğš2,â€¦,ğšn\bm{a}_1, \bm{a}_2, \ldots, \bm{a}_n is cheaper when constructed from the basis than when purchased directly at its own price. Thus, we have
ğ²âŠ¤ğšjâ‰¤cj for j=1,2,â€¦,norğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤. \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j \leq c_j \;\; \text{ for }  j = 1, 2 , \ldots, n \quad
\text{or} \quad \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.

title: 02_duality
text:
Sensitivity


z(ğ›):=minimizeğœâŠ¤ğ±subject toğ€ğ±=ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ.(5)
\begin{align}
z(\bm{b}) := & \operatorname{minimize} &\bm{c}^\top \bm{x} & \\
& \text{subject to} &\bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, & \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align} 
 \qquad(5)

Let the optimal basis be ğ\bm{B} with the corresponding solution ğ±=(ğ±ğ,ğŸ)\bm{x} = (\bm{x}_{\bm{B}}, \bm{0}), where ğ±ğ=ğâˆ’1ğ›\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{B}^{-1}\bm{b}.
A solution to the corresponding dual is ğ²âŠ¤=ğœğâŠ¤ğâˆ’1\bm{y}^\top = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top \bm{B}^{-1}.



Letâ€™s make a small change in the vector ğ›\bm{b}, which will not change the optimal basis. Thus for ğ›+Î”ğ›\bm{b} + \Delta\bm{b}, the optimal solution is ğ±=(ğ±+Î”ğ±ğ,ğŸ), \bm{x} = (\bm{x} + \Delta\bm{x}_{\bm{B}}, \bm{0}),  where Î”ğ±ğ=ğâˆ’1Î”ğ›\Delta\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{B}^{-1}\Delta\bm{b}.
Thus the corresponding increment in the cost function is

z(ğ›+Î”ğ›)âˆ’z(ğ›)=ğœğâŠ¤Î”ğ±ğ=ğ²âŠ¤Î”ğ›.(6) z(\bm{b} + \Delta\bm{b}) - z(\bm{b}) = \bm{c}_{\bm{B}}^\top
\Delta\bm{x}_{\bm{B}} = \bm{y}^\top\Delta\bm{b}.  \qquad(6)





Sensitivity of the optimal cost


ğ²\bm{y} gives the sensitivity of the optimal cost wih respect to changes in the vector ğ›\bm{b}. If a new program were solved with ğ›\bm{b} changed to ğ›+Î”ğ›\bm{b} + \Delta\bm{b}, the change in the optimal value of the objective function would be ğ²âŠ¤Î”ğ›\bm{y}^\top \Delta\bm{b}.




This interpretation of the dual vector ğ²\bm{y} is intimately related to its interpretation as a vector of simplex multipliers.

Since yiy_i is the price of the unit vector ği\bm{e}_i when constructed from the basis ğ\bm{B}, it directly measures the change in cost due to a change in the ithi^{\text{th}} component of the rhs vector ğ›\bm{b}.

title: 02_duality
text:
Sensitivity â€“ Examples

Hence yiy_i may equivalently be considered as a marginal price of the component of bib_i, since if bib_i is changed to bi+Î”bib_i + \Delta b_i, the value of the optimal solution changes by yiÎ”biy_i\Delta b_i.




Diet Problem



yiy_i is the maximum price per unit that the dietitian would be willing to pay for a small amount of the ithi^{\text{th}} nutrient.
Decreasing the amount of the nutrient that must be supplied by food will reduce the food bill by yiy_i dollars per unit.







Production Problem



Manufacturer must select levels x1,x2,â€¦,xnx_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n of nn production activites in order to meet certain required levels of output b1,b2,â€¦,bmb_1, b_2, \ldots, b_m while minimizing production costs.
yiy_iâ€™s are the marginal prices of the outputs.
They show directly how much the production cost varies if a small change is made in the output levels.







Theorem


The minimal value function z(ğ›)z(\bm{b}) of the linear program EquationÂ 5 is a convex function, and the optimal dual solution ğ²*\bm{y}^\ast is a subgradient vector of the function at ğ›\bm{b}, written as âˆ‡z(ğ›)=ğ²*\nabla z(\bm{b}) = \bm{y}^\ast.

title: 02_duality
text:
Sensitivity â€” Subgradient Theorem



Theorem


The minimal value function z(ğ›)z(\bm{b}) of the linear program EquationÂ 5 is a convex function, and the optimal dual solution ğ²*\bm{y}^\ast is a subgradient vector of the function at ğ›\bm{b}, written as âˆ‡z(ğ›)=ğ²*\nabla z(\bm{b}) = \bm{y}^\ast.






Proof


Let ğ±1\bm{x}^1 and ğ±2\bm{x}^2 be two optimal solutions of EquationÂ 5 corresponding to two right-hand-side vectors ğ›1\bm{b}^1 and ğ›2\bm{b}^2, resp. Then, for any scalar 0â‰¤Î±â‰¤10 \leq \alpha \leq 1, Î±ğ±1+(1âˆ’Î±)ğ±2\alpha \bm{x}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{x}^2 is a feasible solution of EquationÂ 5 with ğ›=Î±ğ›1+(1âˆ’Î±)ğ›2\bm{b} = \alpha \bm{b}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{b}^2 so that the minimal value is
z(Î±ğ›1+(1âˆ’Î±)ğ›2)â‰¤ğœâŠ¤(Î±ğ±1+(1âˆ’Î±)ğ±2)=Î±ğœâŠ¤ğ±1+(1âˆ’Î±)ğœâŠ¤ğ±2=Î±z(ğ›1)+(1âˆ’Î±)z(ğ›2)
z(\alpha \bm{b}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{b}^2) \leq \bm{c}^\top (\alpha \bm{x}^1 +
(1-\alpha)\bm{x}^2) = \alpha \bm{c}^\top \bm{x}^1 + (1-\alpha)\bm{c}^\top
\bm{x}^2 = \alpha z(\bm{b}^1) + (1-\alpha)z(\bm{b}^2)

which implies the first claim.
Furthermore, let ğ²1\bm{y}^1 be the optimal dual solution with ğ›=ğ›1\bm{b} = \bm{b}^1. Note that ğ²1\bm{y}^1 remains feasible for the dual of primal with ğ›=ğ›2\bm{b} = \bm{b}^2 because the dual feasible region is independent of changes in ğ›\bm{b}. Thus
z(ğ›2)âˆ’z(ğ›1)=ğœâŠ¤ğ±2âˆ’(ğ²1)(zero-duality gap theorem)â‰¥(ğ²1)âŠ¤ğ›2âˆ’(ğ²1)âŠ¤ğ›1(weak
duality)=(ğ²1)âŠ¤(ğ›2âˆ’ğ›1),
\begin{align}
z(\bm{b}^2) - z(\bm{b}^1) &= \bm{c}^\top \bm{x}^2 - (\bm{y}^1) &
\text{(zero-duality gap theorem)} \\
&\geq (\bm{y}^1)^\top \bm{b}^2 - (\bm{y}^1)^\top \bm{b}^1 & \text{(weak
duality)} \\
&= (\bm{y}^1)^\top (\bm{b}^2 - \bm{b}^1),
\end{align}

which proves the second claim.

title: 02_duality
text:
Complementary Slackness





Theorem (Complementary slackness â€” asymmetric form).


Let ğ±\bm{x} and ğ²\bm{y} be feasible solutions for the primal and dual programs, respectively, in the pair



minimizeğœâŠ¤ğ±subject toğ€ğ±=ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} = \bm{b}, \quad \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align}



minimizeğ²âŠ¤ğ›subject toğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top.
\end{align}




A necessary and sufficient condition that they both be optimal solutions is that for all jj


xj>0â‡’ğ²âŠ¤ğšj=cjx_j > 0 \; \Rightarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j = c_j,
xj=0â‡ğ²âŠ¤ğšj<cjx_j = 0 \; \Leftarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j < c_j.









Proof (of Complementary Slackness)


If the stated conditions hold, then clearly (ğ²âŠ¤ğ€âˆ’ğœâŠ¤)ğ±=0(\bm{y}^\top \bm{A} - \bm{c}^\top)\bm{x} = 0. Thus ğ²âŠ¤ğ›=ğœâŠ¤ğ±\bm{y}^\top\bm{b} = \bm{c}^\top\bm{x}, and by strong duality, the two solutions are optimal.
Conversely, if the two solutions are optimal, it must hold, by strong duality, that ğ²âŠ¤ğ›=ğœâŠ¤ğ±\bm{y}^\top \bm{b} = \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} and hence that (ğ²âŠ¤ğ€âˆ’ğœâŠ¤)ğ±=0(\bm{y}^\top \bm{A} - \bm{c}^\top)\bm{x} = 0. Since each component of ğ±\bm{x} is nonnegative and each component of ğ²âŠ¤ğ€âˆ’ğœâŠ¤\bm{y}^\top\bm{A} - \bm{c}^\top is nonpositive, the conditions 1.1. and 22. must hold.








Theorem (Strict complementary slackness â€” asymmetric form)


Let both the primal and dual problems be feasible. Then there is an optimal solution pair ğ±\bm{x} and ğ²\bm{y} such that for all jj


xj>0â‡”ğ²âŠ¤ğšj=cjx_j > 0 \; \Leftrightarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j = c_j,
xj=0â‡”ğ²âŠ¤ğšj<cjx_j = 0 \; \Leftrightarrow \; \bm{y}^\top \bm{a}_j < c_j.

title: 02_duality
text:
Complementary Slackness





Corollary (Complementary slackness â€” symmetric form)


Let ğ±\bm{x} and ğ²\bm{y} be feasible solutions for the primal and dual programs respectively in the pair



minimizeğœâŠ¤ğ±subject toğ€ğ±â‰¥ğ›,ğ±â‰¥ğŸ.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{c}^\top \bm{x} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{Ax} \geq \bm{b}, \\ 
& \bm{x} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align}



minimizeğ²âŠ¤ğ›subject toğ²âŠ¤ğ€â‰¤ğœâŠ¤,ğ²â‰¥ğŸ.
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{b} \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{y}^\top \bm{A} \leq \bm{c}^\top, \\
& \bm{y} \geq \bm{0}.
\end{align}




A necessary and sufficient condition that they both be optimal solutions is that for all ii and jj


xj>0â‡’ğ²âŠ¤ğšj=cjx_j > 0 \;\; \Rightarrow \;\; \bm{y}^\top\bm{a}_j = c_j,
xj=0â‡ğ²âŠ¤ğšj<cjx_j = 0 \;\; \Leftarrow \;\; \bm{y}^\top\bm{a}_j < c_j,
yi>0â‡’ğšiğ±=biy_i > 0 \;\; \Rightarrow \;\; \bm{a}^i \, \bm{x} = b_i,
yi=0â‡ğšiğ±>biy_i = 0 \;\; \Leftarrow \;\; \bm{a}^i \, \bm{x} > b_i,


where ğši\bm{a}^i is the ithi^{\text{th}} row of ğ€\bm{A}.




Â 
Â 



Economic interpretation



Let us think in terms of the diet problem, which is the primal part of a symmetric pair of dual problems.
Suppose that the optimal diet supplies more than bjb_j units of the jthj^{\text{th}} nutrient.

This means that the dietitian would be unwilling to pay anything for small quantities of that nutrient since the availability of it would not reduce the cost of the optimal diet.

This, in view of our previous interpretation of yjy_j as a marginal price, implies yj=0y_j = 0 which is 4.4. of the Corollary.
